_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



1.0    Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

2.0    Process Description and Regulated Substances

3.0    Worst-Case & Alternate Release Scenarios

4.0     General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

5.0    Five-year Accident History

6.0    Emergency Response Program

7.0    Planned Changes to Improve Safety





1.0    RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



The Kraft Foods Inc. (Kraft) facility in Springfield, Missouri has a good record in preventing and minimizing releases of anhydrous* ammonia.  The Kraft facility has a thorough emergency training program for on-site emergency responders.  The facility has implemented the SAP electronic preventive maintenance system that uses a real time database to track training and inspection dates and issue reminders to responsible groups.



The emergency response policies at the Kraft facility ensure that there is emergency response coverage 24 hours - 7 days per week.  There are also provisions for coordination with outside agencies such as the Springfield Fire Department in the event of an emergency.



*From this point in the Executive Summary, anhydrous ammonia will be synonymous with ammonia.





2.0    PROCESS DESCRIPTION AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES



At this location Kraft manufactures and produces dairy products.  The NAICS code for the primary process at this facility is 311514.  This facility is capable of producing various dairy products including cheese for consumer intake.  Many areas of the plant are refrigerated to preserve the dairy products.  Some of these areas include coolers, chillers, storage tanks, and some processes.  The plant also produces some pasta products  



Kraft has one regulated substance under 40 CFR Part 68: ammonia.  Ammonia is used as a cooling agent in the refrigeration of the foods in the various areas described above.



The ammonia threshold for triggering applicability to 40 CFR 68 is 10,000 pounds. The quantity of amm

onia stored on-site is approximately 109,212 pounds.  Thus, 40 CFR Part 68 is applicable to the Kraft plant in Springfield, MO.

















3.0    Worse-Case & Alternate Scenarios



The "RMP*Comp dispersion model was used to complete an off-site consequence analysis of ammonia dispersion to determine the radius (end-point) of impact on the surrounding community. The RMP*Comp is a computer model developed by the USEPA.



Worst Case: The largest potential release of ammonia would occur with a catastrophic failure of the

high-pressure receiver.  Taking the specific definition of the worst-case from 40 CFR

68.25, the largest quantity of ammonia that can be stored in a vessel is in the high

pressure receiver during a pump-out condition.  The total quantity of ammonia that can be

stored in the high-pressure receiver is 23,138 without administrative controls. 

Since the vessel is located outdoors, it is assumed that the entire 23,138 pounds is released into the atmosphere in 10 minutes.  The release rate is 2,313.8 lb./min. Refined computer modeling using the SLAB model was used to obtain the distance to endpoint which is 0.9 miles.



Alternate Case: An alternative scenario was selected for reporting which has a relatively high probability of occurrence and has a distance to endpoint that extends off-site: an ammonia release from the PRV's on the high pressure receiver which is located approximately 200 ft from the fence line.  This produces a horizontal jet release.  There is no applicable administrative controls or passive mitigation.  Active mitigation of the release is human intervention (PRV is shutdown at 10 minutes from the start of the release). The ammonia vapor cloud was calculated to be above 200 ppm on the ground level at a distance of 0.1 miles.





4.0    GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



Kraft has developed an OSHA PSM program for their ammonia refrigeration systems. At Kraft, ammonia falls under

the RMP Program 3 prevention program which is identical to the OSHA PSM program.  EPA has said that if the process is in compliance with OSHA PSM, then it is in compliance with RMP Program 3.  Thus, Kraft's ammonia PSM has been reviewed and determined to be complete for the RMP document.  



There are several aspects of the ammonia prevention program that are key:



1.  The Utility Service Area design (USA) serves as an excellent safeguard for plant personnel because it greatly reduces the amount of ammonia piping inside occupied rooms.  Since most of the pipe work is out of the way of people and machinery, there is less of a chance of an ammonia release.

2.     The plant maintains good training, certification, and employee awareness of operating procedures.

3.    An electronic control monitoring system and emergency shut down system is in place for the entire engine room process.





5.0    FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



According to 40 CFR Part 68.42(a), there have been no accidental releases at this facility.





6.0    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



As mentioned earlier, this facility has developed an emergency response plan in which plant employees are divided into various management and response teams.  There are nine in-plant contacts for an emergency, a list of these contacts can be found in the Emergency Response Plan.  There are also back-up personnel in the event that the primary incident response personnel cannot be contacted.  The emergency response plan includes information about the frequency of employee emergency response training, as well as a detailed description of the training content.  There are also specific procedures to follow in the event of a fire and ammonia emergency.  Response team members participate in a mock spill cleanup annually.  All trained ER team members have pagers/phones that can be activated.



At the discretion of the Incident Commander, the Springfield Fire Department will be called to provide emergency responders and equipment.

The Springfield Fire Department will also be called for all fire related emergencies.  





7.0    PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



A 5 year revalidation of Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) for ammonia was conducted on the ammonia system at Springfield MO from 7/23/13 to 7/25/13. The PHA team reviewed all past PHA recommendations, validated items that had been addressed, reassessed items that were originally considered complete but less than ideal, validated where nothing has changed past recommendations, developed new recommendations for actions that the team determined inadequate and reviewed all past incidents. There are numerous examples of safety improvements as a result of the PSA results.  These improvements include:



 



PSM Element    Exception    Recommendation    Level 



Employee Participation: No Exceptions Noted

        

Process Safety Information (PSI):No Exceptions Noted

        

Process Hazard Analysis(PHA: No Exceptions Noted

        

Operating Procedures: There are several Line Break documents which have N/A indicated in the Work Order/PM line    Every Line Break should include a reference to a work order, PM, MOC, or project number    1-1 (C)



Training: Initial training was conducted on the Natural Cuts Packaging HVAC in January 2009 but there is no documentation that refresher training has been conducted for those units since the initial training. After further review of the training documents, it appears the training may have occurred but the incorrect equipment number was inserted in the training records    Review all Total Course Curriculum documents and conduct refresher training where dates have passed the three year limit    3-2 (B)



Contractors:No Exceptions Noted    

    

Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR):PSSR's 199, 200, & 201 state that training will be conducted in the next Level I meeting but meeting minutes indicate a discussion was held concerning the  PSSR with no mention of training. When training is conducted in a group meeting, the minutes should include ver

biage of who performed the training along with details of the material that was presented (i.e. SOP#)3-2 (B)



Mechanical Integrity: There is no PM to test high discharge pressure shutdown or low suction pressure shutdown for the ammonia compressors     Testing of the high discharge pressure and low suction pressure shutdown feature on compressors should be performed semiannually as outlined in the recommended PM's located on the Corporate Refrigeration Web Site    2-3 (B)



Hot Work: The two hour follow up requirement on Hot Work Permit dated 4/12/13 was performed 2 ? hours after work was completed, on Hot Work dated 6/25/13 the two hour check was conducted 1 hour after work was completed, and on Hot Work dated 6/30/13 the 30 minute follow up was conducted 2 hours and 5 minutes after work was completed     Hot Work permits should be reviewed and follow ups conducted when the form was not filled out properly    1-2 (C)



Management of Change (MOC): MOC 194 & 200 indicate all employees were trained on 5/14/13 but meeting minutes indicate a discussion was held concerning the MOC completion with no mention of training    When training is performed in a meeting, the minutes must include all details of the training including the SOP number if applicable    3-2 (B)



Incident Investigation:    The "Types of Changes Recommended" and the recommendation sections for II 3330-05 are blank and the "Estimate of Property Damage" on II 3330-06 is indicated  as TBD    All sections of the Incident Investigation document should be populated even if the response is N/A or "no recommendations." Determine if a dollar amount will be assigned to the Estimate of Damage section and if not, indicate as "not required"     1-1(C)



Emergency Planning & Response: No Exceptions Noted        



Compliance Audit:No Exceptions Noted        



Trade Secrets:    No Exceptions Noted
